name: Sigils of Elohim
description: Sigils of Elohim is a free mini-game prelude to Croteam’s upcoming first-person puzzler The Talos Principle that challenges players to solve dozens of challenging sigil puzzles under the watchful eye of Elohim.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows XP/ Vista/ 7/ 8 Memory: 1 GB RAM DirectX: Version 9.0 Storage: 200 MB available space

reviews.review_text: Sigils of Elohim is a puzzle game based on the upcoming 'Talos Principle' game by Croteam which engages users to think to the best of their problem solving abilities. You're given a number of shapes to work with and an overall spectrum to insert them in, just like a puzzle. In fact, Sigils of Elohim is basically like a physical puzzle that you place items in to make fit.  Is Sigils of Elohim better than a physical puzzle? The short answer; yes. The long answer? Sigils of Elohim is all that you could ever want a puzzle to be. It's simple, easy, and at the same time challenging beyond belief. Best of all; It's free.  Sigils of Elohim takes an approach like a typical iOS/Android title (as it's also free to play for those platforms) and works well as a PC game as it engages simple fun into a very complex situation. Making all the pieces fit the puzzle box may look easy but you're taken for a wild ride once you've tried every possible solution that you feel your brain can handle, and still can't manage to solve it. The only limitation is your mind, and your imagination.  You can also use codes in this game to get promo items for 'The Talos Principle' coming soon.

Sigils of Elohim managed to entertain me for the (short) duration I played it, and since it's free that's all I asked for. The screenshots on the store page give a perfectly clear picture of what sort of game this is and the game gives you precisely what you'll expect seeing those screenshots in gameplay. Music is fairly short and you will most likely notice the looping but as the game doesn't take too long to clear it's not too much of an annoyance.

A review for a free game! You can spend much more time by reading this all than trying the game yourself !  Okay I will try to be concise. Do you like tetris? No? Is it because it is rushing you towards putting blocks one after another while not allowing to enjoy the feeling of perfectly fitting corners, rotating the little weight of each block?  Oh, so you do like tetris. But were you ever curious about what would be the gameplay like if there is no additional blocks, just a limited number of them, no possibility of erasing lines, just you, your monochrome blocks, and gameplay area?  If so, this is your game. If you are as cultured as me, then you might see the resemblance between this game and Tangram, supposedly a Chinese game about making shapes from triangle blocks with different sizes. You can use your intuition, your basic understanding of geometry... OR... time to endlessly trying every possibility between 6-8 blocks to fill the table in each level. That is the only bad side of the game, it frequently needs mindless rotating and this dumb strategy is a pretty valid one even for a speedrun.  Other than my this little complaint, this is a pretty good game especially if you consider 1. it is free. 2. it is actually a promotional material. (I heard that the same concept is used in Talos Principle a few times, so a good way of promoting as well) The most thing I like about this game is, it is not trying to be more than what it is, it is a simple puzzle game with few rules and that is that. It does not give any other way of playing it, options do not allow much tweaking etc, and I think this minimal approach helps it. The atmosphere is a relaxing one, and whole design helps this feeling.  What else? Blocks feel good it is as if you are playing with some wooden legos. Music is especially good, getting near masterpiece quality but a bit depressive if you ask me. It made me cry once, since I spent 10+ minutes in a chapter!  To summarize, buy it if you find it less than 0.01. Oh Wait.

Sigils of Elohim is a simple puzzle game, and prequel to The Talos Principle. Sigils of Elohim, plays alot like puzzle Tetris, where your objective is to place the different shaped blocks on a board and fit them all in with no overlap. Overall the concept is simple, but can be challenging. There are, at least in my opinion a decent amount of puzzles in game, currently there are 32, but I hear there may be more added later on. completing each group of 8 puzzles unlocks a code to be used in The Talos Principle. I have got to say the game is worth it though, its free, its simple, and while it has no achievements or leaderboards or anything like that, it is still a worthwhile game. And I have got to say, I really like the soundtrack. There may be only a few songs but they are pretty darn good!

PROS:  + simple but challenging puzzles + relaxing menu/game sound + unlockable rewards for The Talos Principle + FREE!   CONS:  - rather short - no menu options to change settings - some reward codes are already used   Comment:  It's clear that Sigils of Elohim should just motivate you into getting The Talos Principle but it’s actually good if you are into puzzle solving and tetris blocks. Three puzzle packs (A, B, C) have 4 color areas each and every area has 8 levels. So that's 96 FREE levels to test your puzzle skills in. The game isn't casual or very hard, you can find it somewhere in the middle. It even contains a reward for each color area passed but as I read the rewards do not always work in TTP. Because of generators that some people use to generate reward keys without playing this game (apparently contacting the devs could get you new codes). Overall a good game that is short and nothing really special ... but it's free and fun to bend your mind for a while.

A good companion to The Talos Principle. Don't be afraid to play it if you don't own TPP: it's enjoyable as a standalone game and will keep you busy for a few hours with its tetris-esque puzzles. However, if you do own the original game, Sigils of Elohim is also nice because it gives you codes to redeem in TTP to get short messages related to the story. A nice bonus, but nothing too big.

Sigils of Elohim is 72 tetramino puzzles - that is to say, trying to form a solid block (a square or a rectangle) using nothing but a set of tetraminos (basically, four squares stuck together - think tetris) given to you for each puzzle, with a different shape and a different assortment for tetraminos for each one.  It is free, and if you're really dying to solve tetramino puzzles, it has 72 of them... but there's absolutely nothing else to it whatsoever. So, uh, yeah.
